title: How long did it take figuring out how to launch an object into space, and who was the first to do it? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first to do it was the German Army during WWII. Their V2 rocket was the first object to be launched into space (defined as the Karman line - 100km of altitude)…that happened in 1944. Figuring out how to do it is a different matter though - that goes back MUCH further. Rockets have been around since the Chinese started playing around with them in the 13th century. Doubtless they knew that they could make bigger ones that would go higher - so perhaps they thought up the idea of sending one up into space…although it’s unclear whether they understood the concept of “space”. In the western world, it had long been known that the air pressure decreases as you go up a mountain - and it doesn’t take much imagination to envisage an altitude where there would be no air left. Sir Isaac Newton had written about how an object could orbit the Earth in the 3rd volume of his Principia Mathematica (Printed in 1687)…  Newton was thinking of a cannon rather than a rocket - but you certainly could build a rocket that would do that. So precisely who had the idea first is very hard to say. But the German V2 rocket was the first to actually achieve it. (Fun fact: My mother was nearly killed by a V2 - so had it been just the tiniest bit more effective, I wouldn’t be here to tell you about it!)

One could argue that it took thousands of years to figure out how to launch an object into space. Attempts were made in ancient China to ‘reach the heavens’ using rockets. However it was Konstantin Tsiolkovsky that is credited with first devising the rocket equation that would lead humans to enter space.
